repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Second Indigenous and
            Afro-Ecuadorian Peoples Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Indigenous and
            Afro-Ecuadorian Peoples Development Project for Ecuador were
            as follows: the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was unsatisfactory, all other ratings
            are not applicable since the operation is cancelled.  The
            key factors leading to the Government of Ecuador's
            (GOE's) decision not to sign the loan were political
            instability and conflict and, in particular, conflicts
            between national indigenous organizations over the direction
            of the Council for the Development of Nationalities and
            Peoples of Ecuador (CODENPE). Afro-Ecuadorian organizations
            supported the project but were unable to influence the
            government decesion that led to its cancellation. Political
            instability and conflicts surrounding CODENPE created
            repeated delays in fulfilling Ecuador's internal
            requirements for signing the loan. Only the first of seven
            steps required signing the loan, the Ministry of Economy and
            Finances' (MEF's) project validation, had been
            completed by GOE in January 2005. By February 2005, MEF had
            decided that the original declaration of priority issued by
            the planning secretariat had expired, and returned the
            project to the starting point of the internal approval
            process. CODENPE and the Afro-Ecuadorian Development
            Corporation (CODAE) continued to make attempts to advance
            the process but these were unfruitful. The Bank's Task
            Team, together with both Sector Management Unit (SMU) and
            Country Management Unit (CMU) management, remained engaged
            throughout the period, through missions and visits and via
            the permanent engagement of the country office. Updating the
            agreed action plans and reminding authorities of the steps
            required, but the agreed activities were not completed.

9753766.trustfund:
TF052532-PHRD-ECUADOR: SECOND INDIGENOUS
            AND AFRO-ECUADORIAN PEOPLES DEVELOPMENT
9753766.majtheme: Rural development,Environment and natural resource management,Social dev/gender/inclusion

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Second Indigenous and
            Afro-Ecuadorian Peoples Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project aims to promote the
            empowerment and improved access to natural and financial
            resources for indigenous and Afro-Ecuadorian communities
            within the framework of their own development. The project
            has the following five components: Component 1) will benefit
            indigenous and Afro-Ecuadorian membership organizations with
            the following technical assistance (TA) and training
            activities: (1) management capacity building; (2) strategic
            and local participatory development planning; (3) legal,
            management, and technical training; and (4) equity in gender
            and generations. Finally, (5) it will provide technical
            assistance to local governments in order to help them
            improve their targeting and participatory practices and
            increase cofinancing of investment subprojects. Component 2)
            will help target groups improve their human capital as well
            as their knowledge base and cultural assets, thus
            contributing to increased incomes. It will include the
            following activities: (i) a scholarship program for higher
            education; and (ii) training and technical assistance
            subprojects for culture-based initiatives in tourism and
            handicrafts among others. Component 3) will help the target
            population improve management of natural resources through
            increased access and control of land, water and other
            natural resources vital for their livelihood. Component 4)
            will finance demand-driven small-scale investment
            subprojects by eligible communities for: (i) investment
            studies; (ii) social investments; (iii) community productive
            investments; (iv) and environmental/natural resource
            management. Component 5) will increase Government of
            Ecuador's (GOE's) capacity to formulate
            intercultural policies and programs taking into
            consideration the concerns of indigenous and Afro-descendant peoples.

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Second Indigenous and
            Afroecuadorian Peoples Development Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Project seeks to promote the
            empowerment, and improved access to natural, and financial
            resources for indigenous, and Afro-Ecuadorian  communities,
            within the framework of their own development and
            inter-cultural aspects. This environmental assessment is
            based on the country's environmental laws and
            regulations, and on international environmental standards,
            and, environmental checklists will be available to profile,
            and identify within each subproject, potential environmental
            adversity. Subprojects will be classified as: category A,
            which includes activities concerning biodiversity
            conservation, sustainable agricultural practices,
            reforestation, integrated management of micro-basins, small
            scale crop management; alternative energy, i.e., solar
            energy, hydraulic energy, etc. These will not require an
            environmental assessment; Category B, with subproject
            proposals for agricultural extension practices requiring
            soil fertility improvement, drainage, afro-forestry
            practices, livestock productivity in fragile areas, or in
            areas rich in medicinal plants, shall require an
            environmental assessment, while those subprojects under
            Category C that includes construction of irrigation systems,
            in addition to agro-industries such as agro-processing,
            infrastructure development will require an environmental
            impact assessment process, and as needed, specific studies
            that address the environmental requirement in each case.
            Category D subprojects will not be financed by the project,
            and these activities include: proposals within protected
            areas, deforestation, aquaculture activities in protected
            areas, dam construction, new roads in protected areas,
            introduction of foreign or exotic species, and, the use of
            pesticides. Monitoring and evaluation practices will be in
            place to ensure environmental compliance with appropriate
            waste disposal in selected sites; groundwater, and surface
            waters protection; water quality management; re-vegetation
            practices with native species.
